text: Hi Andrew, what is Tag Matching?
Broadly just matching 2 resources from different sources based on tag metadata associated with the resource.
Specifically for us we match cloud costs with OpenShift using those tags.

So very simple example someone tags their RDS database in AWS with `openshift_application: cost-management` and then tags some pods in OpenShift with `openshift_application: cost-management` we would pick up the cost of that database and associate it with an OpenShift cluster.
Hey I'm about to merge the pyupbot changes, I solved the merge conflict, do you have any feedback before I do that? <https://github.com/project-koku/koku/pull/1317>

attachments.title: #1317 Scheduled weekly dependency update for week 43

text: Yes, don’t. It’ll cause builds to fail in OpenShift.
oh, ok.
And here’s why…
We currently build everything using the Pipfile.lock. and pyup does not update the lock file’s overall hash when it updates packages.
So it goes and computes the hash and finds a conflict and fails out.
But if you pull that branch and run `pipenv lock` then push that change it should be mergable.
Also talk with Michael about this as he was investigating ways to get around this and get it back to automated again.
Because it’s a huge pain right now to have this automatic thing that isn’t at all automatic.
Huge being a very subjective word here. :smile:
So, running `pipenv lock` does what pyupbot is supposed to do anyway right?
Ya.
But do talk with Michael. He had some ideas here.
If you’re interested in the “fix”
question: is everything built with Pipfile.lock in Travis?
I noticed all the Travis tests passed
before running `pipenv lock`
but after pyupbot updated hashes
so is travis still using the old hashes?
travis uses tox which uses `pipenv install --dev --ignore-pipfile` so that must be fine.
So it’s really about the OpenShift build.
That at least used to fail on a mismatched hash.
Worth seeing if that is still a thing.
It’s possible we’re all good, and it doesn’t really matter any more.
Which would be neat.
how do I know if a hash is correct or not?
Well if there’s changes to the file and the hash didn’t update it’s definitely not correct. Since the hash is unique (excluding the rare collision) based on the content of the file.
what about when the hash does update?
for example in this PR: <https://github.com/project-koku/koku/pull/1317/files>
specifically this commit: <https://github.com/project-koku/koku/pull/1317/commits/386548a882ce2f2f09b30ec6087e2a41ce4532f7>
but… this PR now looks like that has been updated.
gotcha
Would be awesome if it’s just getting updated now.
i ran pipenv lock as the last commit to this PR
Oh you did it. I see now.
Cool.
it's ok to merge now?
Yeah, but let’s hold off a bit as there’s a handful of critical bug fixes going in and I don’t want to back them up with long travis runs again.
Just a little bit.
what time of day do you think would be best in general, for when this is automated?
im guessing sometime around midnight EST
is there anyone in India working on Koku?
No, there is not.
So in general, it’s just another PR. Probably better to do it during working hours for us in case it does cause some problem.
We do have people in the UK and Europe using CI, so don’t want to leave it in a bad state for them.
